paragraph: _Hort_ is a mediæval and Old High German word with the meaning of “collected and guarded treasure”; Gothic, _huzd_; Old Scandinavian, _hodd_; Germanic _hozda_, from pre-Germanic _kuzdhó_—for _kudtho_—“the concealed.” Kluge[706] adds to this the Greek κεύθω, έκυθον = “to hide, to conceal.” Also _hut_ (_hut_, to guard; English, hide), Germanic root _hud_, from Indo-Germanic _kuth_ (questionable), to Greek κεύθω and κύσθος, “cavity,” feminine genitals. Prellwitz,[707] too, traces Gothic _huzd_, Anglo-Saxon _hyde_, English hide and hoard, to Greek κεύθω. Whitley Stokes traces English hide, Anglo-Saxon _hydan_, New High German _Hütte_, Latin _cûdo_ = helmet; Sanskrit _kuhara_ (cave?) to primitive Celtic _koudo_ = concealment; Latin, _occultatio_.The assumption of Kluge is also supported in other directions; namely, from the point of view of the primitive idea:“There exists in Athens[708] a sacred place (a Temenos) of Ge, with  the surname Olympia. Here the ground is torn open for about a yard in  width; and they say, after the flood at the time of Deucalion, that  the water receded here; and every year they throw into the fissure  wheatmeal, kneaded with honey.”
question: What other languages and terms are linked to the word "Hort," and how do they relate to the concept of concealment?
answer: The term "Hort" is linked to several other languages and terms that relate to the concept of concealment. It is connected to Germanic _hud_ from Indo-Germanic _kuth_ (questionable), which is also associated with the Greek words κεύθω and κύσθος. Additionally, the English words "hide" and "hoard" are traced to Gothic _huzd_ and Anglo-Saxon _hyde_, which are also related to the Greek κεύθω.
